conclusion: To determine whether Object A and Object B have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \), we need to analyze the slopes of their velocity-time graphs at that specific time.

Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. Mathematically, it can be represented as: \[ a = \frac{dv}{dt} \]. In a velocity-time graph, the slope of the tangent line at any given point represents the acceleration at that point.
At time \( t_1 \), the velocity of Object A is changing linearly with time. The graph shows a straight line segment for Object A between \( t=0 \) and \( t=t_2 \).

premise: The graph shows a straight line segment for Object A between \( t=0 \) and \( t=t_2 \).
conclusion: The slope of this straight line segment can be calculated using the formula for the slope of a line: \[ \text{slope} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \]. Since the line is straight, the slope (and hence the acceleration) is constant throughout this segment. Therefore, the acceleration of Object A at \( t_1 \) is the same as the slope of this line.
At time \( t_1 \), the velocity of Object B is changing nonlinearly with time. The graph shows a curved segment for Object B.

premise: The graph shows a curved segment for Object B.
conclusion: To find the acceleration at \( t_1 \), we need to find the slope of the tangent line to the curve at \( t_1 \). From the diagram, the tangent line to the curve of Object B at \( t_1 \) appears to be different from the slope of the straight line segment for Object A.

premise: The slope of the straight line for Object A is constant and can be visually estimated. The slope of the tangent line for Object B at \( t_1 \) is less steep than the slope of the line for Object A.
conclusion: Since the slopes are different, the accelerations of Object A and Object B at \( t_1 \) are not the same.

premise: Since the slopes are different, the accelerations of Object A and Object B at \( t_1 \) are not the same.
conclusion: No, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \).
